body:
@hbanzhaf Thanks for posing this question. 

The path to `mlruns` directory will depend on where you run your python code with the mlflow code to track your entities. By default, this will be in the `mlruns` directory. And within it, a directory '0' with the `meta.yaml` that will have a path stored in it. The default experiment is always "Default," if you don't specify a name. 

If you move your python code elsewhere and run it, a new `mlruns` directory is created where the path for the `artifact_location` is different from the previous run in that directory. 

To ensure that have a consistent `artifact_location` if you are running experiments on your localhost, we recommend that you decide
ahead of time where you want artifact store and the backend store to be. Once decided, launch your tracking server with those arguments. For example: `mlflow server --backend-store-uri file:/tmp/issue_3114 --default-artifact-root /tmp/issue_3114`

This will launch the mlflow tracking server on your `http://127.0.0.1:5000`.  Use this URI in the code.

Here is the example code:
```
import joblib
import mlflow
from mlflow.tracking import MlflowClient

if __name__ == '__main__':
   with open('test.file', 'wb') as f:
      test = range(20)
      joblib.dump(test, f)
   mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://127.0.0.1:5000")
   exp_info = MlflowClient().get_experiment_by_name("issue_3114")
   exp_id = exp_info.experiment_id if exp_info else MlflowClient().create_experiment("issue_3114")
   with mlflow.start_run(experiment_id=exp_id) as run:
      run_id = run.run_id = run.info.run_uuid

      params = {"n_estimators": 3, "random_state": 0}
      mlflow.log_params(params)
      mlflow.log_artifact('test.file')

      print(f"artifact_uri={mlflow.get_artifact_uri()}")
      print(f"run_id={run_id}")
```

Output from  the code:

 ```
artifact_uri=/tmp/issue_3114/0/616239e0c63140d884f3fedde71916a3/artifacts
 run_id=616239e0c63140d884f3fedde71916a3

```
This will always have the same `artifact_location` from wherever you run the python code with your mlflow code in it. It no longer will
create a `mlruns` directory at the same location as where your code runs or resides. 

Does this answer your question?  

Regardless of where you run your MLflow code, `artifact_location` will remain the same for all experiments; with this suggested best practice, there's no `mlruns` directory. 

cc: @arjundc-db

Thank you for your fast answer. Unfortunately, this does not resolve my problem yet. I use the function `mlflow.set_tracking_uri()` to set the path to the `mlruns` folder. Sometimes, this folder must be moved to another location (due to various reasons). If I then run the `mlflow ui` in the new location (in order to once again look into the results of this experiment), the UI shows me all logged parameters and metrics, but not the artifacts. How can this be resolved without manually adapting the paths in the `meta.yaml` to the new location of the `mlruns` folder?

The `--default-artifact-root`, by design, is something that we reckon does not change frequently in production for a number of reasons: people want to backup their artifacts for data disaster and recovery; use of efficient and reliable cloud or on-premise storage for scalability and replication. So changing and moving `--default-artifact-root` frequently is not a best practice. 

On the other hand, in your case, if you are running different experiments and you want these to be distinct and saved in distinct locations then set up different locations and bring up your `mlflow ui` with the respective experiment, rather than moving `mlruns` locations.

Hi, @dmatrix, if I understand correctly, there is no way to remap the artifact locations when launching the interface with `mlflow ui`. Everything should be predetermined. IMO, this would be a bit inconvenient, as pulling results containing artifacts from the remote servers will inevitably result in path mismatch. Or is there any quick method to fix this mismatch, when the artifacts are saved without too much care of configuration? Is it possible to set a relative path for the artifact locations?

I would like to second this request.

Relative paths should be possible!

This seems like it might be related to:
following this issue: mlflow/mlflow#2671
and this PR: mlflow/mlflow#2753

From my point of view the issues #2671 and #2753 are not related to the problem.
I am facing the same problem. I ran my experiments on one machine but I need to visualize the UI results on another. Unfortunately I can't make a HTTP connection between each other. So I believed that copying the mlruns content would solve my problem. 
Is there any reason to store artifact_uri with an absolute path instead of a relative path in meta.yaml ? Change to a relative path manually works to me.
Tx

I am also facing the same problem. I run my experiments on a remote HPC server. I cannot visualize the results on the HPC server (no x window, no HTTP access). 
I have to download the mlruns folder to my local machine to visualize the results. However, the artifacts are stored in the absolute path and I cannot access them using mlflow UI. 
The capability to use a relative path instead of an absolute path would be very important.

> I am also facing the same problem. I run my experiments on a remote HPC server. I cannot visualize the results on the HPC server (no x window, no HTTP access).
> I have to download the mlruns folder to my local machine to visualize the results. However, the artifacts are stored in the absolute path and I cannot access them using mlflow UI.
> The capability to use a relative path instead of an absolute path would be very important.

Until this issue is fixed you can use [mlf-core's fix-artifact-paths](https://mlf-core.readthedocs.io/en/latest/fix_artifact_paths.html).
@Zethson's tool works for me. It would be great if this was supported within mlflow itself, I don't think this is a rare use case.
